revision.text:
</noinclude>{{Use dmy dates|date=September 2016}} {{Infobox artwork | title = Girl with Balloon | painting_alignment = | other_language_1 = | other_title_1 = | other_language_2 = | other_title_2 = | wikidata = | image = Banksy Girl and Heart Balloon (2840632113).jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = Original mural on [[Waterloo Bridge]] in [[South Bank]] in 2004 | artist = [[Banksy]] | year = {{start date|2002}} | completion_date = <!-- For a more specific date (post-1583): {{start date|YYYY|MM|DD|df=y}} --> | catalogue = | medium = | movement = | subject = | height_metric = <!-- (i.e. in metric units) --> | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = <!-- (i.e. in imperial units) --> | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = cm <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | imperial_unit = in <!-- Note: this parameter must either use the value given or not be included --> | weight = | designation = | condition = | museum = | city = | coordinates = <!-- Only use for the coordinates (when known) of the artwork itself, i.e. not for the site, building, structure, etc where it is kept, otherwise leave blank (or omit): {{coord|LAT|LON|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} --> | owner = | accession = | preceded_by = <!-- preceding work by the same artist --> | followed_by = <!-- next work by the same artist --> | module = | website = <!-- Official webpage/site only: {{URL|example.com}} --> }} '''''Girl with Balloon''''' (also, '''''Balloon Girl''''' or '''''Girl and Balloon''''') is a 2002-started London series of [[Stencil graffiti|stencil murals]] by the graffiti artist [[Banksy]], depicting a young girl with her hand extended toward a red heart-shaped [[Toy balloon|balloon]] carried away by the wind. The first work was on [[Waterloo Bridge]], and other murals were around London, though none remain there. Banksy has several times used variants of this design to support social campaigns: in 2005 about the [[Israeli West Bank barrier|West Bank barrier]], in 2014 about the [[Refugees of the Syrian Civil War|Syrian refugee crisis]], and also about the [[2017 United Kingdom general election|2017 UK election]]. A 2017 [[Samsung]] poll ranked ''Girl with Balloon'' as the United Kingdom's number one favourite artwork.
In 2018, a framed copy of the work spontaneously shredded during an auction, by way of a mechanical device Banksy had hidden in the frame. Banksy authenticated he was responsible for the shredding and gave the altered piece a new name, ''[[Love is in the Bin]]''. Sotheby said it was "the first work in history ever created during a live auction."
==History== [[File:BANKSY LONDON.jpg|thumb|right|This variation in London, seen above in 2006, was the last one in the city, painted over in 2007.]] The first mural was in 2002 at the stairs for [[Waterloo Bridge]] on the [[South Bank]] side. A number of other mural versions were also created in London, though, mostly painted over, none of the works by Banksy are remaining.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hxb9BgAAQBAJ&pg=PT24|title=Banksy Locations & Tours Volume 1: A Collection of Graffiti Locations and Photographs in London, England|last=Bull|first=Martin|date=2011-11-01|publisher=PM Press|isbn=9781604863208|language=en}}</ref> A 2004 version of the mural was at an east London shop in [[Shoreditch]], sold in 2007 for £37,200 at [[Sotheby's]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/entertainment/6340109.stm|title=Record price for Banksy bomb art|date=8 February 2007|accessdate=17 December 2015|publisher=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> and was removed by the Sincura Group in 2014 and sold for £500,000 in September 19, 2015.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-26022513 |title=London Banksy Girl and Balloon mural to be removed |last=McDermott |first=Josephine |date=7 February 2014 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
Several sets of [[Edition (printmaking)|limited edition prints]] of the work were produced, which became valuable over time. An initial set of 25 signed prints was produced in 2003,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/london/2018-03-08/banksy-girl-and-balloon-canvas-smashes-auction-estimate/|title=Banksy 'Girl and Balloon' canvas smashes auction estimate|work=ITV News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/24744/lot/44/|title=Bonhams : Banksy (British, born 1975) Girl and Balloon 2003|website=www.bonhams.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref> while a set of 150 signed prints and a set of 600 unsigned prints were produced in 2004/2005.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.picturesonwalls.com/|title=picturesonwalls|website=www.picturesonwalls.com|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.myartbroker.com/artist/banksy/girl-with-balloon/|title=Banksy Girl With Balloon (2004), Meaning & Description, My Art Broker|work=My Art Broker|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}}</ref> In November 2015, one of the signed set of 150 was auctioned for £56,250, more than twice its estimated value.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.itv.com/news/westcountry/2015-11-25/banksy-print-makes-more-than-a-picasso-at-auction/|title=Banksy print makes more than a Picasso at auction|work=ITV News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en}}</ref>
In August 2005, Banksy included it as part of a series of murals on the [[Israeli West Bank barrier|West Bank barrier]], a variation called ''Balloon Debate'' of the girl [[Cluster ballooning|floating above]] the wall while holding onto a bunch of balloons.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.com/culture/story/20171215-how-a-balloon-can-be-an-emblem-of-hope|title=How a balloon can be an emblem of hope|last=Grovier|first=Kelly|date=2017-12-15|website=BBC|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thecrimson.com/column/the-art-of-protest/article/2014/3/26/the-art-of-protest-banksy/|title=Banksy and the Wall|last=Kim|first=Adela H.|date=2014-03-26|website=The Harvard Crimson|language=en|access-date=2018-10-15}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://news.artnet.com/opinion/banksy-sothebys-art-shredded-1368280|title=Can We Just Admit That Banksy's Art-Shredding Stunt Is Actually Really Good?|last=Davis|first=Ben|date=2018-10-10|work=artnet News|access-date=2018-10-15|language=en-US}}</ref>
A 2009 version was sprayed directly onto the cardboard backing of an [[IKEA|Ikea]] frame.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/entertainment-arts-17559526|title=Banksy artworks sell for £400,000|date=2012-03-30|work=BBC News|access-date=2018-10-16|language=en-GB}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bonhams.com/auctions/20195/lot/237/|title=Bonhams : Banksy (b. 1975) Girl and Balloon 2009 signed and inscribed For Mike. Thanks on the reverse stencil spray paint on cardboard, in integral frame 54 by 74 cm. 21 1/4 by 29 1/8 in. This work was executed in 2009.|website=www.bonhams.com|language=en-gb|access-date=2018-10-16}}</ref>
In March 2014, the third anniversary of the Syria conflict, Banksy reworked the painting to depict a Syrian refugee and added the [[hashtag]] #WithSyria. On 13 March, the image was projected on the [[Eiffel Tower]] and [[Nelson's Column]]. An animated video was released, featuring animation based on Banksy's work, narration by [[Idris Elba]], and music by [[Elbow (band)|Elbow]].<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/banksy-reworks-girl-with-heart-balloon-to-mark-third-anniversary-of-syria-conflict-9187047.html |title=Banksy reworks girl with heart balloon to mark third anniversary of Syria conflict |author=Jess Denham |date=12 March 2014 |work=The Independent |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref> In the following weeks, the singer [[Justin Bieber]] got a tattoo based on the original art and posted a picture of it on Instagram before deleting it. Banksy posted this picture on his Facebook page with the comment "Controversial".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.co.uk/2014/03/18/justin-bieber-banksy-tattoo-graffiti-artist_n_4984389.html |title=Justin Bieber's Banksy Tattoo Blasted By The Graffiti Artist, Sort Of |date=18 March 2014 |work=The Huffington Post UK |accessdate=7 March 2016}}</ref>
In July 2017, a [[Samsung]] poll of 2,000 people from the United Kingdom asked participants to rank twenty pieces of British art. The poll's results listed ''Balloon Girl'' as the people's number one favourite artwork.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-40717821 |title=Banksy's balloon girl chosen as nation's favourite artwork |date=26 July 2017 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=29 July 2017}}</ref>
===United Kingdom general election controversy=== In early June 2017 before the [[2017 United Kingdom general election|United Kingdom general election]], Banksy introduced a variant of ''Girl with Balloon'' with the balloon coloured with the [[Union Jack]] design.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.itv.com/news/2017-06-03/banksy-offers-free-art-print-to-those-who-vote-against-the-conservatives/ |title=Banksy risks breaking election law with offer of art prints for anti-Conservative voters |publisher=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |date=3 June 2017 |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> Banksy initially offered to send a free print of his art to registered voters in certain constituencies who could offer photographic proof they had voted against the [[Tories (British political party)|Tories]]. The offer included a disclaimer: "This print is a souvenir piece of campaign material, it is in no way meant to influence the choices of the electorate."<ref>{{cite web |last=O'Connor |first=Roisin |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/art/news/general-election-2017-banksy-free-print-vote-against-conservative-party-theresa-may-eu-brexit-a7772341.html |title=Banksy is offering free art to people who vote against the Tories |date=4 June 2017 |work=Independent |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> Banksy cancelled this offer on 6 June 2017 after the [[Electoral Commission (United Kingdom)|Electoral Commission]] warned him it could violate election [[bribery]] laws and invalidate the election's results in those constituencies.<ref>{{cite web |last=Morris |first=Steven |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2017/jun/06/bansky-free-election-artwork-bristol-withdrawn |title=Banksy forced to withdraw offer to send free artwork to non-Tory voters |date=6 June 2017 |work=The Guardian |accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref>
===Shredding at auction=== {{Main|Love is in the Bin}} On 5 October 2018, a 2006 framed copy of the artwork was auctioned at Sotheby's selling for £1,042,000 – a record high for the artist.<ref name=martinez/> Moments after the closing bid, the artwork began to self-destruct by means of a hidden mechanical paper shredder that Banksy had built into the frame bottom.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-bristol-45770028 |title=Banksy artwork shreds itself after £1m sale at Sotheby's |date=6 October 2018 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=6 October 2018}}</ref> Only the lower half shredded. Banksy released an image of the shredding on Instagram with the words "Going, going gone..".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/oct/06/banksy-sothebys-auction-prank-leaves-art-world-in-shreds-girl-with-balloon |title=Banksy auction prank leaves art world in shreds |first=Chris |last=Johnston|date= 6 October 2018 |work=The Guardian }}</ref> Sotheby's said "We have not experienced this situation in the past where a painting spontaneously shredded",<ref name=martinez>{{cite web |url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/apos-appears-just-got-banksy-144105925.html |title='It Appears We Just Got Banksy-ed.' Art Piece Self Destructs After Being Sold for Over $1 Million |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |agency=[[Yahoo! News]] |author=Gina Martinez |date=October 6, 2018 |accessdate=October 7, 2018}}</ref> leading some market watchers to speculate the remains of the painting will be worth even more.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.apnews.com/5f8911d839ce42e6a2ffc62f2cdf6074 |title=Banksy artwork self-destructs just after $1.4 million sale |publisher=Associated Press |author=Jill Lawless |date=7 October 2018 |accessdate=8 October 2018}}</ref> Banksy released a video of the shredding and how the shredder was installed into the frame in case the picture ever went up for auction.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/video/2018/oct/07/banksy-publishes-video-detailing-auction-prank-plan-video |title= Banksy publishes video detailing auction stunt plan – video |date=7 October 2018 |work=The Guardian}}</ref>
The woman who won the bidding at the auction decided to go through with the purchase. The partially shredded work has been given a new title, ''Love Is in the Bin'', and was authenticated by Banksy's authentication body Pest Control. Sotheby's released a statement that called it "the first artwork in history to have been created live during an auction."<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2018/oct/11/woman-who-bought-shredded-banksy-artwork-will-go-through-with-sale |title=Woman who bought shredded Banksy artwork will go through with purchase |first=Mattha|last= Busby|date=11 October 2018|work=The Guardian }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://news.artnet.com/market/banksy-re-authenticates-shredded-1-4-million-european-buyer-will-keep-1369852 |title=Banksy Authenticates and Renames His Shredded $1.4 Million Painting—Which the Buyer Plans to Keep|first=Eileen|last= Kinsella|date=11 October 2018 |work=artnet}}</ref>
